entry.title: The Future of Amusement Parks: How SAP Powers the Next Wave of Thrill & Technology
entry.content:
The Future of Amusement Parks: How SAP Powers the Next Wave of Thrill & Technology

When I attended the SAP Top Architect Bootcamp, I expected to deepen my understanding of SAP solutions‚Äîand I certainly did. But what surprised me was how often my thoughts drifted back to the world I live in every day: the amusement-park industry, where I‚Äôve spent the past two years shaping experiences, studying operations, and watching how technology transforms guest expectations.

As a mother, my visits to theme parks with my son have also given me a unique, personal perspective. Watching his excitement, his curiosity, and how he interacts with attractions helped me see first-hand how the future of theme parks must evolve.

So, with every SAP capability I explored‚Äîacross CX, analytics, BTP, AI, and sustainability‚ÄîI couldn‚Äôt help but imagine: What would the theme park of the future look like for me and my son?

  1. Personalised Guest Experiences ‚Äî The Magic of SAP CX

The Story Begins:

The moment my son and I scan our tickets, our park experience transforms.

My phone buzzes with a personalised route suggestion‚Äîhighlighting shorter queues, shaded rest spots, and our favourite attractions. Meanwhile, my son receives a notification from his wearable wristband inviting him to meet his favourite character nearby. This hyper-personalised experience is powered by SAP CX.

  • Builds rich guest profiles for both adults and children, tailoring our journey. We can enhance the same using SAP Customer Data Platform - https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/customer-data-platform.html which seamlessly integrates into a 360¬∞ customer profile.
  • Sends AI-driven recommendations‚Äîlike a quiet snack zone when kids need a break. This can be leverage with SAP Emarsys - https://www.sap.com/products/crm/emarsys.html  as  it offers personalised suggestions
  • Personalised bundles for families, child-specific deals, and dynamic pricing. This can be achieved  SAP Commerce Cloudhttps://www.sap.com/india/products/crm/commerce-cloud.html.
  • Smooth, intuitive interfaces across mobile and wearables. SAP Build Apps ( https://www.sap.com/india/products/technology-platform/low-code-app-builder.html) and Spartacus (https://community.sap.com/t5/crm-and-cx-blog-posts-by-members/introduction-to-spartacus/ba-p/13418581) can help us to build intuitive interfaces.

For families like ours, this means a day that feels designed just for us.

  1. Immersive AR/VR Worlds ‚Äî Powered by SAP BTP

The Adventure Expands:

As my son and I stroll through the enchanted forest zone, he suddenly gasps. A digital dragon appears‚Äîhovering above us, reacting to his movements and responding to his excitement. He chases it playfully, and the AR storyline adapts in real time to his reactions.

That magic is orchestrated by SAP BTP:

  • Ensuring AR storytelling adapts to our real-world location . SAP Event Mesh can be used to achieve the same(https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite/capabilities/event-mesh.html)
  • Links my son‚Äôs wearable profile so the experience feels personal. SAP Integration Suite can be used for personalised and dynamic experience.(https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite.html)
  • Behind the scenes, analytics help the park understand which experiences engage you most, enabling continuous optimization of these immersive zones and this can be achieved by SAP Analytics Cloud (https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html).    

These immersive experiences create unforgettable moments‚Äîfor children and adults alike.

  1. Intelligent Park Operations ‚Äî AI, IoT & Automation at Work

As my son and I enjoy our day, SAP technology silently ensures everything runs flawlessly.

  • Monitoring of ride safety in real time, giving parents like me peace of mind .SAP IoT(https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_IoT/fffd6ca18e374c2e80688dab5c31527f/3c61bd1bedc4473fbd952e92b5e7cf8d.html) sensors monitor ride performance in real time, ensuring that everything operates at peak performance.
  • Technicians use AR-guided repairs to minimize downtime which can be managed by SAP Field Service Management (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/field-service-management/what-is-field-service-management.html).
  • AI ensures enough staff are available at family-heavy zones. SAP SuccessFactors  - https://www.sap.com/india/products/hcm.html.
  • Streamlines operations so staff can focus on guest care. SAP Build Process Automation can be used for automating the manual processes.https://www.sap.com/india/products/technology-platform/process-automation/features.html

This invisible intelligence creates a smoother, safer experience‚Äîespecially for families with young children.

  1. Sustainability at the Core ‚Äî Enabled by SAP‚Äôs Green Solutions.

As we walk, I feel proud showing my son how the park embraces sustainability. Showing him recycling stations that are intelligently placed based on crowd flow, solar panels integrated into ride structures, and sustainable materials used in the food packaging and merchandise, enhance my son‚Äôs understanding of sustainability.

SAP can helps us to enable this shift by using products like 

  • SAP Sustainability Control Tower (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/sustainability-control-tower.html) for environmental analytics
  • SAP Responsible Design & Production  (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/responsible-design-and-production.html) for greener materials
  • SAP Waste Management  (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/8a399f5444164440ac4f426e847ec901/7567bd534f22b44ce10000000a174cb4.html) powered by IoT.
  • SAP Green Ledger (https://www.sap.com/india/products/financial-management/green-ledger.html) tying sustainability to financial accountability.

This creates a park not just fun‚Äîbut responsible.

  1. Data as the Heartbeat of the Connected Park

For families like mine, the magic is seamless‚Äîbut behind the scenes, data orchestrates is everything. Every twist, turn, and laugh in the park is driven by data. You might not see the data at work, but it‚Äôs there, ensuring the best possible experience for you, every step of the way.

From real-time ride performance to the preferences of every guest, SAP can be used to unify data, ensuring that everything works in harmony.

SAP‚Äôs data-driven approach can be helpful every part of the park:

  • All guest and operational data is integrated into one foundation, enabling real-time, personalised experiences. SAP Datasphere ( https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/datasphere.html ) can be leverage for the same 
  • Systems like ticketing, AR/VR, and mobile apps needs to work seamlessly together to create a unified digital experience and this can be managed  by SAP Integration Suite (https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite.html)
  • Predictive analytics help the park optimize everything from crowd flow to ride performance, ensuring an efficient and exciting day for all visitors. Here we can use SAP Analytics Cloud (https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html) to help to do Predictive analytics.
  • Advanced AI models forecast guest behaviour, allowing the park to continuously enhance experiences and predict future trends. SAP AI Core (https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/serviceCatalog/sap-ai-core) can be leveraged for the same.

üåü The Future of Fun, Built on SAP ‚Äî For Families, For Dreamers, For Everyone

As my son and I leave the park, tired but smiling, I realise this is what the next generation of amusement parks must deliver‚Äîa world where operational excellence, cutting-edge technology, and deeply personal experiences collide.

entry.title: Enhancing Migration Efficiency Through Controlled SUM DMO Table Splitting
entry.content:
Understanding Table Splitting in SUM DMO

In a DMO or Downtime Optimized DMO (doDMO) scenario, application table transfer occurs across specific SUM phases:

  • EU_CLONE_CP2STAB_RUN ‚Äì Uptime phase (DMO & doDMO)

  • EU_CLONE_MIG_OPTDMO_INI_RUN ‚Äì Uptime phase (doDMO only)

  • EU_CLONE_MIG_DT_RUN ‚Äì Downtime phase (DMO & doDMO)

The preparation and calculation of table split logic occurs in corresponding preparation phases, all of which operate during uptime. This design allows proactive configuration before the critical migration execution begins.

While standard SUM behavior is sufficient for most systems, extremely large tables may require enforced customization to ensure balanced workload distribution and better utilization of parallel R3load processes.

Real-Time Issue Faced

During S4HANA upgrade with migration, a large tables like BALDAT with table size of 150GB and other tables with large size consuming excessive time in the table splitting phase. 

As a result, SUM extended runtime and this behavior directly contributed to increased downtime (i.e. 28Hrs27mins) risk and inefficient resource utilization.

 

Strategic Intervention Applied

Instead of relying solely on default parameters, we introduced controlled overrides in SUM configuration files to optimize splitting behavior.

Table-Specific Custom Splitting

We explicitly defined split fields by creating the following configuration file:

<SUM_DIR>/abap/control/EUCLONEDEFS_ADD.LST
And added as shown in below screenshot.

Syntax used:

Inhibit splitting of a table:
<TABLENAME> nosplit
Split a table into a defined number of segments:
<TABLENAME> segmentsize=0.02
Note: The segmentsize value is calculated as 1 / <number_of_splits>.
For example, 0.02 represents 50 segments for the table.

This ensured SUM enforced controlled segmentation of the table into predefined buckets, enabling predictable workload distribution and stable split calculation behavior.

 

Results Achieved

Following this intervention:

  • Large tables were processed in controlled parallel segments

  • SUM phases stabilized significantly

  • Overall downtime reduced measurably compared to earlier dry runs

  • Resource utilization became more balanced and predictable

This strategic tweaking allowed us to ensure smoother system availability and meet strict business downtime SLAs.

Downtime without table splitting took 28Hrs27mins

Downtime with table splitting took 12Hrs27mins

 

Key Takeaways

  • SUM default behavior is reliable but may not suit extreme data volumes.

  • Manual parameter tuning should only be performed by experienced SAP consultants.

  • Real-time log analysis is essential to identify root causes in splitting failures.

  • Controlled split field definition can resolve non-ASCII and key field selectivity issues.

  • Optimized parallelism improves both uptime processing and downtime efficiency.

 

Conclusion

This experience highlights how intelligent optimization of SAP SUM table splitting can play a crucial role in achieving successful S/4HANA upgrades. By leveraging advanced configuration parameters responsibly, we transformed a potential bottleneck into a controlled and efficient migration process.

For consultants handling large-scale systems with high-volume tables, understanding and applying these optimizations can be the difference between extended outages and seamless transitions.

 

Reference

This implementation approach is aligned with guidance from SAP Note 3386079 ‚Äì SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration, which provides expert-level control options for influencing SUM table splitting and migration behavior.

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2511 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New?
entry.content:
With the November release of SAP Business Network for Logistics, we‚Äôre delivering important updates designed to refine the user experience and boost operational efficiency. These enhancements apply to the applications we deliver, elevating usability and enabling better collaboration across logistics processes. In this blog post, we‚Äôll outline the new features and capabilities introduced in this release.

Specifically, please note the availability of the following features requested in influence portal:

  • Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace: Tracking harmonization
  • Freight Collaboration ‚Äì Settlement: Enable or disable dispute management in external system for freight orders and freight bookings
  • Freight Collaboration ‚Äì Settlement: Mark invoices as ‚Äòsettled outside‚Äô
  • Global Track and Trace: View calculated and actual emission and forward to TM

 

Tracking Harmonization across SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace

With SAP Business Network for Logistics release 2511, SAP harmonizes freight execution tracking across SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration and SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace. There is a new, harmonized tracking experience and a shared Web UI for manual event reporting‚Äîthe ‚ÄòManage Freight Execution‚Äô app ‚Äîwhich provides a consistent look for role-appropriate views by shippers and carriers, and ties events to a central tracking table accessible from both Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace.

This unification consolidates information shared across FC, Dock Appointment Scheduling, and GTT. As part of the product roadmap, the legacy apps ‚ÄòTrack Freight Movement‚Äô for FC shippers and ‚ÄòFreight Orders for Reporting‚Äô for FC carriers are planned for deprecation in May 2026. GTT solution owners gain an additional reporting channel, enabling data contributors to report events via the Web UI.

Tracking harmonization is related to the release of the following features:

  • New application ‚ÄòManage Freight Execution‚Äô for event reporting and management in Web UI
  • Adaptation in supported tracking use cases:
    • App deprecation: ‚ÄòFreight Order for Reporting‚Äô and ‚ÄòTrack Freight Movement‚Äô apps will be sunset in May 2026
    • TransportationOrderGenericTrackedProcessRequest_Out SOPA interface now supported in Global Track and Trace

For more details on tracking harmonization, please access our detailed blog post, the ‚ÄòManage Freight Execution‚Äô how-to video or the feature detail deck.

 

Please note, there is also a dedicated webinar on tracking harmonization scheduled for November 26th. 

Register here!

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration and SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace

‚ÄòProvider API for order events (FC and GTT)‚Äô no longer supports some special characters  

In the ‚ÄòProvider API for Order Events (GTT)‚Äô and ‚ÄòProvider API for Order Events (FC)‚Äô, special characters such as ‚Äúasterisk (*)‚Äù and ‚Äúquestion mark (?)‚Äù are no longer allowed in the attachment file name. For a complete list of unsupported characters, see SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Application URL updated

Following company-wide top level domain change for SAP-owned SaaS applications and SAP Business Network domain naming conventions, the domain name in the application URLs of SAP Business Network for Logistics has been updated from the previous ‚Äòcfapps.<data center>.hana.ondemand.com‚Äô to ‚Äòlogistics.<data center>.business-network.cloud.sap‚Äô.

It allows you to easily recognize SAP brand by the URL and seamlessly navigate between SAP SaaS Applications without changing cookie settings.

You will be redirected to the new URL automatically when accessing the applications with old URLs. Remember to update your bookmark as needed.

Change in December 2025 Release Date

The date of the productive upgrade for the LBN 2512 release was changed from December 6, 2025, to December 13, 2025.

Message Implementation Guidelines updated

The following message implementation guidelines have been updated:

  • Message Implementation Guideline (ANSI X12 214 FC)
  • Message Implementation Guideline (ANSI X12 214 GTT)
  • Message Implementation Guideline (IFTMIN D96A)

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Dock Appointment Scheduling: restricted access to gate logbooks

In the ‚ÄòManage Gate Operations‚Äô app, you can now restrict access to gate logbooks based on the yard location ID.

For more information, see Enabling Role-Based Access in SAP Help Portal.

Settlement: enable or disable dispute management in external system

In the ‚ÄòGeneral Settings‚Äô app, the dispute management settings have been modified. You can now enable or disable dispute management in external system for freight orders as well as freight bookings.

 

Settlement handle freight booking disputes in ‚ÄòManage Disputes‚Äô app

Building on the above new feature, shippers can now manage disputes related to freight bookings directly in the ‚ÄòManage Disputes‚Äô app.

Settlement: mark invoice as ‚Äòsettled outside‚Äô

In the ‚ÄòInvoice Freight Documents‚Äô app, a new button has been introduced on the worklist page as well as the detail view page. When carriers settle a freight document outside of SAP Business Network for Logistics , they can choose this button and select ‚ÄòMark as Settled Outside‚Äô.

 

 

You can also undo this action by choosing the ‚ÄòUnmark as Settled Outside‚Äô option.

Please note: freight documents marked as ‚ÄòSettled Outside‚Äô will no longer appear in the ‚ÄòTo be invoiced‚Äô tab, but only in the tab ‚ÄòAll‚Äô.

Settlement: new filter in ‚ÄòInvoice Freight Document‚Äô app

In relation to the above feature, a new filter has been introduced in the ‚ÄòInvoice Freight Document‚Äô app to filter on ‚Äòcancelled‚Äô and ‚Äòupdated‚Äô invoices as well as invoices ‚Äòsettled outside‚Äô (see above screenshot).

 

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace

Rate limiting adapted

Rate limiting has been adapted for IDOC and SOPA message interfaces as well as Write Service API and Read Service API.

‚ÄòManage Models‚Äô app: field visibility management enabled

In the ‚ÄòManage Models‚Äô app, a new 'visible' attribute has been added to model fields to control their display in the fulfillment-tracking apps. When enabled, the corresponding field will be shown in those apps.

Please note: as of now, you can only manage the visibility settings for user-defined fields.

‚ÄòTrack Shipments‚Äô app: ‚ÄòReporting Party‚Äô information added

To replace the sender party, a new field called 'Reporting Party' has been added in the ‚ÄòReporting History‚Äô section of the Shipment Details page and the ‚ÄòInformation‚Äô tab on the event details page. This field indicates who reported the event, and clicking the link opens a popover with the detailed contact information for that party.

‚ÄòTrack Shipments‚Äô app: format unified for planned gross duration and planned net duration

To improve user experience and readability, the ‚Äòplanned gross duration‚Äô and ‚Äòplanned net duration‚Äô has been adapted.

‚ÄòTrack Shipments‚Äô app: view calculated and actual emission and forward emission data to TM

This new functionality is one of our release highlights!

Receiving emission data for logistics processes and understanding scope 3 emissions can be highly complex, involving multiple stakeholders and many manual tasks.

Now, it has become much easier, as SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace can integrate with SAP S4/HANA TM to share carbon emissions. 

Transportation planners can:

  • Use SAP Business Network to connect to many carriers or visibility providers
  • Receive emission data for logistics processes

The emissions table on the ‚ÄòShipment Details‚Äô page now shows calculated GHG emissions when TM provides the values in SAP S/4HANA, and the header displays a quick validation by comparing reported and calculated emissions.

Further, we enabled automatic forwarding of shipment emissions data to TM in SAP S/4HANA, reducing manual work and improving data accuracy.

For more details on this feature and enablement steps, please access this deck.

Note, there is also a video showcasing the feature in action.

 

SAP Business Network, intelligent insights add-on

Deprecation of import of business SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration content into SAP Analytics Cloud

The business content for SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration is now deprecated. You can't import its predefined analytics content in the content network of SAP Analytics Cloud.

However, this does not affect the existing imported business content. You can still display it in dashboards.

 

---------------------

The above summarizes the key innovations for 2511. We hope you enjoy the new capabilities. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2511 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

SELECT RSPOS,

entry.title: Re: How to store price with 4 decimals
entry.content:
Dear @Zong,

In Public Cloud you cannot truly store or post THB amounts with more than 2 decimals but you can model a 4-decimal rate using the Pricing Unit (and, if needed, units of measure). That‚Äôs the standard, SAP-consistent workaround.

Question 1.

In Public Cloud currency amounts are hard-limited to 2 decimals, and customers cannot change this via CBC:

  • SAP Note 3632144 explicitly states that in Public Cloud it‚Äôs not possible to change the number of decimal places from the standard two-decimal format for currency amounts.
  • The help around condition records for pricing also states that the system supports amounts only to 2 decimal places, values with 3+ decimals are rounded when saved.

So:

  • You cannot change THB to 4 decimals.
  • You cannot make PR00 store 0.3456 THB directly as an amount in Manage Prices Sales app it will always round to 0.35 THB.

More details below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003632144

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/306837/?section=sectionDetails

Question 2.

Yes, within the constraints of Public Cloud, this is exactly the pattern SAP tends to recommend.

For Public Cloud SAP Note about not being able to enter 4 decimals for price condition types (e.g. PPR0) points to the same limitation and discusses workarounds, it does not offer a way to extend currency decimals.

More details below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003450476

So you can definitely treat use Pricing Unit as an SAP-standard method rather than a hack.

Question 3.

In Public Cloud there is no other standard way to store 0.3456 THB as a true 4-decimal currency amount.
The only SAP-standard modeling pattern within pricing is the Pricing Unit

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/b2a4b6024aa54e30af5a523ff62f43bc.html

https://me.sap.com/notes/3278921

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: S/4 HANA 2025 - ABAP Cloud Outbound http Client
entry.content:
Seems that Communication Targets are the common layer to using Clean Core APIs for http outbound communication, while the set-up behind the CoTA is different for on-prem vs. cloud

on-premise outbound http communication (S/4 HANA 2025): 

  1. Communication Target +
  2. Transaction APPLDEST config +
  3. STRUST certs for https

 

 

 

public cloud outbound http client:

  1.  Communication Target + 
  2.  Destination System +
  3. Communication Arrangement

 

__PRESENT

entry.title: Re: Hierarchy upload from S/4 publich cloud to BW4H
entry.content:
Hello Tom,

We are currently experiencing the same issue (same error message) when extracting the G/L account hierarchy data (from an S4H public cloud system).

We were able to determine the cause by debugging.

The cause is that there are hierarchy nodes (values) that are delivered to BW from the source system with leading zeros (see long text in the GUI for the specific data or the screenshot). The conversion exit ALPHA in BW during updating (TRF rule for field HIERARCHYNODE (CHAR50) to IOBJ 0H_HIERNODE (CHAR32) and the active conversion routine ALPHA at the IOBJ 0H_HIERNODE definition), the leading zeros are deleted during processing and two (or more) identical values are created for the hierarchy node.

example:
Hierarchy nodes: 0003 and 003 become ‚Äò3‚Äô in the update! See the screenshot of our DTP termination.

 

Unfortunately, the attempt to deactivate the ALPHA conversion exit in the TRF rule for the above mentioned update rule was unsuccessful, i.e., we wanted to force the system to retain the leading zeros during loading (with different numbers of leading zeros and thus retaining different values as they are delivered from the source; '0003' and '003' are two different values/characteristics).

We have not attempted to deactivate the ALPHA conversion routine directly at IOBJ 0H_HIERNODE, as the object is very central and is used in several HIER-TRFNs (side effects are unpredictable for existing data flows) and, furthermore, this IOBJ cannot be adapted by SAP. You get an error message saying that the IOBJ is protected and cannot be edited.

 

Regarding the current OSS call, I can report that SAP has not yet shown any willingness to address this issue. We are therefore currently working on a workaround that is practicable for us and has been successful so far.

  1. Workaround: Start routine in TRFN for HIER load to IOBJ (simplified logic):
    1) Search for all data records in the source package in segment 3 (HIER structure) with leading zeros in the HIERARCHYNODE field.
    2) optional: Limit yourself to the data records that represent hierarchy text nodes (= filtering on field FIELDNM = ‚ÄòHIERARCHYNODE‚Äô, so that the leaves of the hierarchy of, for example, GLACCOUNT are not selected).
    3) Replace the first leading zero (it would also be possible to replace all leading zeros) with a capital ‚ÄòO‚Äô as in 'Otto'. Of course, another letter is also possible, such as ‚ÄòZ‚Äô.
    4) The result (according to the above example) is that ‚ÄòO003‚Äô and ‚ÄòO03‚Äô are processed and the conversion exit is thus ‚Äúswitched off‚Äù or has no effect (with regard to the elimination of leading zeros).

Note: In our first attempt, we worked with a prefix, i.e., we prefixed the values ‚Äò0003‚Äô and ‚Äò003‚Äô with ‚ÄòGL‚Äô (GL0003 and GL003). We rejected this approach because, in our view, there is another problem in the HIER data flows, for which we have submitted another OSS call to SAP (which SAP is not particularly helpful about).

The field ‚ÄòHIERARCHYNODE‚Äô, which is mapped to 0H_HIERNODE in BW4 for updating, has CHAR50. The target IOBJ 0H_HIERNODE, on the other hand, only has CHAR32 !!! This inevitably leads to data loss if the key has more than 32 characters. SAP has apparently not transferred the extraction from an S4H public cloud system cleanly to the BW4 content. According to the current state of discussions, SAP is also not prepared to provide a new CHAR50 IOBJ in the content (as a replacement for 0H_HIERNODE). Furthermore, no other Z-objects can be used with HIER-TRFN itself. So far, however, we have not received any values longer than 32 characters in the HIERARCHYNODE field from the source. But this is not technically impossible (in the source table in S4 ‚Äòhrrp_node_n‚Äô, the data element: hrynode also has CHAR50). By replacing the first leading zero instead of a prefix, we at least do not ‚Äúlose‚Äù any digits.


Overall, HIER extraction from S4H public cloud is currently not a satisfactory situation in BW4. It appears that BW development is not communicating with S4 development, or that nothing is being adjusted in BW4. Furthermore, it is not possible to make the necessary changes to the objects in question (neither in S4 public cloud nor in BW4)!


Best regards,
Joachim

entry.title: What‚Äôs New for Services Procurement in the SAP Fieldglass November 2025 Release
entry.content:
With every release, SAP Fieldglass unveils innovative features aimed at elevating user experience, boosting efficiency, and delivering better business outcomes. The November 2025 release is no exception with many exciting enhancements and expanded functionalities in the Services Procurement module. Read on to find out more about some key updates in this area.

What‚Äôs New for Services Procurement in the SAP Fieldglass November 2025 Release:

  • Reopen Statements of Work (SOWs) Regardless of Status
    Users can now reopen closed SOWs in any status, eliminating the previous restriction that only allowed SOWs that had been in approved status to be reopened. When a closed SOW is reopened, it will automatically return to the status it held prior to closure, streamlining the process and ensuring business continuity.

  • Copying SOWs with Workers: Retaining Consolidated Worker Records
    When copying an SOW, the Workers assigned to the original SOW can now be duplicated onto the new SOW with the system maintaining their Consolidated Worker Records. This update prevents inconsistent worker data which could impact downstream systems and lead to issues with access, inadvertent worker record termination, tenure calculation, etc.

  • Event Hierarchy Generation with AI
    The November 2025 release saw many enhancements to the powerful Event Hierarchy feature, including the option to use generative AI to automate the creation of Event Hierarchy content, reducing manual effort while improving data consistency and completeness.
    Some of the other key updates to this feature include:
    • New Decimal Precision Field for Event Hierarchy Units
    • Default Event Hierarchy Custom Lookup on SOW Creation
    • Enhancements to the Event Approval Process
  • Create a Resource Type
    There were also many exciting enhancements introduced to the Resource and Resource Time Sheet features, including the new Resource Type that can now be created with Labor and Equipment as the available Type options.
    Other key updates include:
    • Automated Approvals for Resource Time sheets Leveraging Tolerance Limits
    • View Account Categories of the Cost Centers while Creating a Resource Time Sheet
    • Distinguish Time Based Work from Non Time Based Work on a Resource Time Sheet

Want to Learn More?
To find out more about the features listed above, watch the short Services Procurement 2025.11 Release Highlights video.

For more information on the Event Hierarchy, Resource, and Resource Time Sheet features, check out the Best-in-Class Services Procurement: SAP Fieldglass and Contracts and Resource Management Focus: SAP Fieldglass Services Procurement videos.

entry.title: capacity leveling in public cloud
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are upgrading from R3 to S4 public cloud. In our company, we schedule all operations for production orders. In R3, we can schedule operations of an order separately, but in S4, when I schedule one operation, the others are scheduled immediately before or after it. Is there a way to schedule the operations of an order across different time slots?

thanks in advance.

entry.title: Integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing
entry.content:
Integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing

Follow the below blog from Nageshcaparthy and want to highlight couple of things which this blog didn‚Äôt cover and couple of changes were needed in SAP help document which is informed to SAP product team during my interaction.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-integration-with-sap-ariba-setup-guide/ba-p/14240003

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/integration-with-sap-ariba

We should consider 2 scenarios

  1. Customers who have already integrated SAP Ariba with SSO.
  2. Those who are 1st time implementing SAP Ariba with SSO and integrating with SAP Joule

Scenario 1:

Since we belong in this category I want to share changes observed during this whole process and my experience through this article.

Activation of Joule and formations were already in place and SAP Successfactor integration completed successfully.

Comparing the steps from the blog and at the same time highlighting the changes

  1. Steps involved during this integration
  1. SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services (ICM Process) ‚Äì completed
  2. OAuth Credentials for CDM API (SAP Ariba Developer Portal) ‚Äì We needed not only these keys but SCIM API for User and Group Master Data.
  3. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from SAP Ariba Applications to IAS
    1. Create Ariba to IAS User Sync - Source System
    2. Create Ariba to IAS User - Target System
  4. Integrating Joule
  • Have an existing Joule setup, and a formation has been created
  1. Post-integration checks
  • Validate Application List
  • Validate the Attributes
  • Trusted Domains
  • Conditional Authentication
  1. Destination Setup
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations
    1. SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations ‚Äì DT
    2. SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations ‚Äì RT
  1. SAP Build Work Zone - Content Provider 
  • Content Provider for SAP Ariba Sourcing Solutions
  • Channel Updates
  1. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from IAS to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Configure the Source System
  • Configure Target Systems
    • SAP Ariba Sourcing ‚Äì Target
    • Run Sync Job

During my session along with SAP Development team it was clarified that the users sync from IAS to Ariba were not required as it was not required since SAP Ariba was already integrated with IAS for SSO and users in both were already in Sync.

please read the disclaimer from referred blog.

  1. SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services

since this configuration is already in place and ensured that joule activation was done using the same IAS tenant which was used earlier for integration with SAP Successfactor and the same should be used for other LOB‚Äôs. If other LOBs are configured with different IAS tenants then you may have to migrate them to this IAS tenant it will be really challenging. As highlighted in my earlier blog this requires proper planning for unification of all the SAP LOBs into a single IAS tenant.

We had details discussion with SAP Team about the critical aspect of GUID (SCIM ID) ‚Äì All along I had an impression that GUID were required for user authentication and conversations and it requires to send this information from IAS to Ariba which was not required as Ariba doesn‚Äôt depend on it entirely rather it uses other attributes of the user like email ID and Login name even though Ariba uses S4HANA in the backend it is completely controlled from Application side.

 The question will arise what about S4HANA either cloud or on-premise systems to be integrated with Joule how the GUID will be taken care of. It entirely depends on the way the users from IAS to these LOBs are sync. Once we achieved it part of Task center implementation is that the GUID of uses from IAS were updated into S4HANA on premise (existing setup) using BADI. You can refer to any blog or online information you will find the details.

As per the blog we changed the url from ondemand.com to cloud.sap with the help of Ariba team since as customer you don‚Äôt have an option to change it.

Since already we had the existing setup of Ariba integration with IAS there are no source and target systems created in IDP.

Thankfully the blog has provided the json files for source system and target system which we used and manually created them for replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS.

In the blog and in help document it is mentioned that once the above step is completed we should have the necessary bundled applications, Source, target systems in IAS which didn‚Äôt happen in our case since we already had the necessary application defined manually for integration of Ariba with IAS. I recommend this to be included in any of the blogs or in the help document so that customer is aware of it.

Sourcing system

Target system

  1. OAuth Credentials for SCIM API (SAP Ariba Developer Portal)

Follow the steps mentioned in the blog and the difference is we faced issue with replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS and after session with Ariba team advised us to create SCIM API in place CDM API created using workzone CDM Content and these details are meant to use in source system of users and groups replication from IAS to Workzone. The details of SCIM API requested through SAP Ariba Development Portal. It is possible to get both API‚Äôs by creating the incident as we didn‚Äôt find the workzone CDM API in the portal and it is created and sent to us by Ariba team except creation of secret which can be done by the administrator of portal.

3.1 Create Ariba to IAS User Sync - Source System

Created the source system using the json files provided in the blog and used the SCIM API created earlier in the Development portal.

3.2 Create Ariba to IAS User - Target System

The user and password are taken from a system user created in the administrator console with client ID and secret by providing only the necessary auth. to manage users and groups.

Followed other recommendations provided in the blog to remove some property parameters

Replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS is successful. check the below details from provisioning logs.

Note: Moment of caution again don‚Äôt sync user replication from IAS to Ariba which is not required it may differ in terms of specific cases and would advise to take the help of Ariba team.

  1. Integrating Joule

As we already had the existing setup of joule with formations ready we added the Ariba realm and ended with the issue below. Not providing complete details as they are already covered in the blog.

Synchronization was failing as it was unable to identify already created application in IAS. After weeks long investigation by Joule and Ariba product development team they created one more application other than already existing one added the missing client ID inside the attributes of the application, and we were able to add the Ariba tenant successfully into the formation.

Production development still they are trying to figure out the issue and hopefully in subsequent release the process will identify the existing application in IAS which will create the necessary bundle application under the main application.

After successfully adding the Ariba tenant still joule icon was not appearing in the Ariba tenant and further it was resolved by Ariba team after activating feature toggles in Ariba tenant.

  1. Post-integration checks

Follow the validation of attributes, application, Changes in the trusted domain, Conditional authentication at IAS as mentioned in the blog.

  1. Destination Setup

Follow and create destination of Design time and runtime as mentioned in the blog and use the files provided in github.

https://github.com/SAP-samples/btp-onboarding/tree/main/docs/Joule-with-SAP-Ariba/JSON-Files

  1. SAP Build Work Zone - Content Provider
  • Content Provider for SAP Ariba Sourcing Solutions

Following the steps mentioned in the blog and initial update will fail since still users and groups were not replicated from IAS to Ariba.

  1. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from IAS to SAP Build Work Zone

We had issue with creation of source system in IDP for replication of users and groups ( As per the blog it should create automatically once the IAS tenant is added in to ICM which didn‚Äôt create in our case) json files were also missing in the blog. Requested the product development to add them into the same github repository.

Followed the help document to create the source and target systems in IDP.

Execution of sync job should be successful once you ensured that property parameters in both source and target systems are properly maintained.

Now if a refresh is done for SAP Ariba strategic sourcing in Workzone it should be updated successfully.

verify whether the groups are assigned to the users..

I had an interesting discussion with SAP Product team why not Ariba also follows the same way users and groups are replicated from SF to WZ during integration of SAP Successfactor with Joule (where they are directly moved from SF to WZ by passing the IAS where IAS is used only for authentication). In Ariba the users and groups are replicated from Ariba-IAS-WZ. The explanation is that both products are different in the way they interact with BTP. SF is part of BTP whereas Ariba is completely different SAAS product.

 

  1. Joule Test Scenarios

Follow the use cases from the below link. Test each case end to end understand all the scenarios application like Informational, Transactional, Navigational.

Note that beyond the scenarios what are explained and configured to work in Joule don‚Äôt execute in you natural language as you won‚Äôt find a proper response.

Each interaction user make with joule and response received will be treated as one token and as I mentioned in my earlier blog ‚ÄúAriba integration with SAP successfactor ‚Äúyou are entitled for fixed number messages free and after that you will be charged so understanding the scenarios and educating the business users adhering to it is critical as of now. Not sure if SAP increases the number of messages free.

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/capabilities-guide/joule-in-sap-ariba-solutions

 

Conclusion: The Next Generation of Procurement

The integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing is a significant step toward an AI-driven, friction-less procurement process. This implementation journey, especially for customers with existing SSO configurations, underscores that while official documentation is really useful but it requires changes for both scenarios mentioned.

Key Takeaways and Future Focus

This experience highlights several vital points for organizations embarking on this integration:

  • IAS Unification: The seamless integration of Joule across multiple Line of Business (LOB) applications, like SuccessFactors and Ariba, hinges on the unification of all LOBs to a single SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) tenant. This prevents complex migration challenges and ensures a cohesive user experience.

  • User Sync: For customers already integrated via SSO, the blog's requirement for a separate IAS-to-Ariba user sync can be potentially eliminated or simplified, as Ariba primarily relies on existing attributes like email and login name for authentication, not the GUID/SCIM ID for conversation context, which is the main dependency for other applications like S4HANA, SuccessFactors and SAP concur.

  • Beyond the Standard API: The need to request the SCIM API in addition to the standard OAuth Credentials (CDM API) for user and group replication from Ariba to IAS is a practical detail that requires a proactive approach with the SAP Ariba development team.

  • The Maturing Platform: The initial issues faced with the Joule application identification in IAS and the subsequent need for Ariba team intervention to activate feature toggles demonstrate that the Joule integration architecture, while robust, is still actively maturing. Future releases are expected to streamline the automatic identification and bundling of applications within IAS.

In summary, this integration has successfully delivered the conversational and transactional capabilities of the Joule AI Copilot into the SAP Ariba Sourcing landscape. As SAP continues to invest in generative AI, understanding these practical implementation insights will be crucial for other enterprises to achieve a truly unified, intelligent, and highly efficient procurement experience while maximizing the value of their existing SAP ecosystem.
